instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.ALL_SYS: What is ALL_SYS? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALL_SYS, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.C1950: What is C1950? Capacitor between PP3V42_G3H & ground on pin 8 of U1950 on 2013-2015 Macbook Pros & Airs that often corrodes. When corroded, pin 8 on U1950 will be damaged, which will prevent machine from booting and cause PM_SLP_S4_L to pulse. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> CPU high temperature.
threads.message:
Good afternoon, the cpu heats up a lot, idle, just using youtube.
I cleaned the ME Bios Region, but it keeps warming up.
Repaired previously in the <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> region.



[ATTACH type="full"]59627[/ATTACH][ATTACH type="full"]59628[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> CPU high temperature.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> CPU high temperature.
threads.message: I just changed the thermal folder, now it is not turning on. When I remove the <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR>, it turns on again. It already replaces <RESISTOR>R8166</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R8165</RESISTOR>, <CAPACITOR>C1950</CAPACITOR> and <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>, but it's still intermittent.  <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> 0.012V; PPbus 8.6V; PP3v42 3.42V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> CPU high temperature.
threads.message: Leave <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> out of board; redundant protection, not really needed.
